title: 1383-B
statement: B. GameGametime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputKoa the Koala and her best friend want to play a game.The game starts with an array $$$a$$$ of length $$$n$$$ consisting of non-negative integers. Koa and her best friend move in turns and each have initially a score equal to $$$0$$$. Koa starts.Let's describe a move in the game:During his move, a player chooses any element of the array and removes it from this array, xor-ing it with the current score of the player.More formally: if the current score of the player is $$$x$$$ and the chosen element is $$$y$$$, his new score will be $$$x \\oplus y$$$. Here $$$\\oplus$$$ denotesbitwise XOR operation.Note that after a move element $$$y$$$ is removed from $$$a$$$.The game ends when the array is empty.At the end of the game the winner is the player with the maximum score. If both players have the same score then it's a draw.If both players play optimally find out whether Koa will win, lose or draw the game.InputEach test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 10^4$$$) — the number of test cases. Description of the test cases follows.The first line of each test case contains the integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 10^5$$$) — the length of $$$a$$$.The second line of each test case contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\ldots, a_n$$$ ($$$0 \\le a_i \\le 10^9$$$) — elements of $$$a$$$.It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case print:WINif Koa will win the game.LOSEif Koa will lose the game.DRAWif the game ends in a draw.ExamplesInput3 3 1 2 2 3 2 2 3 5 0 0 0 2 2OutputWIN LOSE DRAWInput4 5 4 1 5 1 3 4 1 0 1 6 1 0 2 5 4OutputWIN WIN DRAW WINNoteIn testcase $$$1$$$ of the first sample we have:$$$a = [1, 2, 2]$$$. Here Koa chooses $$$1$$$, other player has to choose $$$2$$$, Koa chooses another $$$2$$$. Score for Koa is $$$1 \\oplus 2 = 3$$$ and score for other player is $$$2$$$ so Koa wins.

processed.result:
Two players take turns playing a game with an array of non-negative integers.  

Here's how the game works:

1. **Starting Score:** Both players begin with a score of 0.
2. **Player Turn:** On each turn, a player chooses an element from the array and removes it. They then add the value of the chosen element to their score using the bitwise XOR operation ($ \oplus $).
3. **Game End:** The game ends when the array is empty.
4. **Winner:** The player with the highest score at the end of the game wins. If both players have the same score, it's a draw.

Given an array, determine if the first player (Player 1) will win, lose, or draw if both players play optimally.

Two players take turns removing numbers from a list.  Each time a number is removed, the player XORs it with their current score. The player with the highest score at the end wins. Determine if the first player will win, lose, or draw assuming both players play optimally.
